page.title: 15th World Festival of Youth and Students

revision.comment: removed grandparent category of [[Category:2001 in Algeria]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox summit | summit_name = 15th World Festival of Youth and Students | other_titles = | image = | alt = | caption = | country = Algeria | date = {{Start date|2001|08|08}}-{{End date|2001|08|16}} | motto = Let's globalize the struggle for Peace, Solidarity, Development, against Imperialism | venues = | cities = [[Algiers]] | participants = 11,000, from 110 countries }} The '''15th [[World Festival of Youth and Students]]''' (WFYS){{cite web|url=http://www.wfys15.dz/anglais/default.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010331074749/http://www.wfys15.dz/anglais/default.htm |archivedate=2001-03-31 |title=15th World Festival of Youth and Students |author= |date=31 March 2001 |website=WFYS15 |publisher=WFYS |accessdate=12 December 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }} was organized by the [[World Federation of Democratic Youth]] (WFDY) in [[Algiers]], [[Algeria]], from 8 to 16 August 2001 for nine days, under the slogan "Let's globalize the struggle for Peace, Solidarity, Development, against Imperialism". The festival was the first organized in an Arab country, as well as the first in Africa and brought together 11,000 delegates from over 100 countries from around the world. International preparatory meetings took place in Cuba, India, Cyprus and Algeria itself. The event came after the successful revival of the festival movement at the 14th World Festival of Youth and Students in [[Havana]], [[Cuba]], and marked a continuation of the internationalist and anti-imperialist youth festival spirit.{{cite web |url=http://www.themilitant.com/1999/636/636_6.html |title=International Youth Meeting In Cyprus Discuss World Festival, Fight Against Imperialism |last1=Malapanis |first1=Argiris |last2=Kelly |first2=Ryan |date=15 February 1999 |website=The Militant |accessdate=12 December 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.themilitant.com/2000/6428/642862.html |title=Meeting in Havana calls world youth festival in Algeria |last1=Haras|first1=Aris |last2=Perasso |first2=Jake |date=17 July 2000 |website=The Militant |accessdate=12 December 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.themilitant.com/2001/6533/653305.html |title=Youth at international festival discuss fight against imperialism |last1=Malone |first1=Alfonse |last2=Chevrier |first2=Natalie |date=27 August 2001 |website=The Militant|accessdate=12 December 2013}} == From the call to the festival ==
The international festival’s movement initiated in the beginning of 1947 offered to the youth of the world a space of free expression around their preoccupations and a forum of solidarity with people searching for independence, for self determination and for development. Humanity is entering the 21st century with hopes and new aspirations, but it has to face at the same time great challenges, being aware that not all of the last centuries changes changed our lives for the better; rather, it depends on our youthful, common and joint struggle as an active power of peoples. The 15th edition of the World Festival of Youth and Students comes to strengthen the work of the last festivals, and will take place in a new millennium marked by disastrous effects of globalisation and the new restructuring of the international relations, under the slogan adopted by a consensus “Let us globalise the struggle for peace, solidarity, development, against imperialism”. This 15th WFYS also plays a great role in an era where the civil society at the international level has become an undeniable partner in taking decisions thanks to multi-form struggles led by Non Governmental Organisations which lay down them selves as a real ways and means of claiming and expressing the preoccupations of the different stratum of peoples.
== Political unrest == The festival took place at the conclusion of the decade-long [[Algerian Civil War]]. In the months leading up to the festival there were sustained street actions by hundreds of thousands of working people and youth in Algeria protesting repression by national police forces and supporting the struggle by the indigenous [[Berber people]], an ethnic nationality in Algeria and throughout North Africa, for the right to be taught in their native language in school. This led to some groups to call to boycott the festival from those communities. == Delegations == Over 1,000 youth from Algeria itself attended the festival including 50 students of Berber origin and whose families live in Kabylia, a region to the east of Algiers where Berbers comprise the overwhelming majority. A number of other countries from Africa sent significant delegations, including Syria, Iraq, Lebanon, Yemen, Sudan, Egypt, and Tunisia, a first time in the history of the WFYS. A large delegation of over 400 people came with the [[Polisario Front]] from [[Western Sahara]] who raised the issue of their ongoing conflict with Morocco, organizing solidarity tents, dinners, rallies, workshops, and cultural activities about the issue which created thousands of refugees in that country. Almost 1,000 youth were expected from the Americas with Cuba sending a delegation of 600, the largest from the region. This included 250 international students who were then going to school in Cuba, especially from Latin America, the Caribbean, and Africa; the other 350 were Cuban students and young workers. Several hundred came from Venezuela, Haiti, the Dominican Republic, the United States and Puerto Rico. The final count for the festival was 11,000 although other sources put the event at 6,500 people. == Stamp == To honour the festival, Algeria released a special stamp by artist and painter Djazia Cherrih featuring the logo of the youth festival.{{cite web |url=http://www.stampsoftheworld.co.uk/wiki/Algeria_2001_15th_World_Festival_of_Youth_and_Students|title=Algeria 2001 15th World Festival of Youth and Students |author= |date=5 March 2012|website=Stamps of the World |publisher=Stamps of the World |accessdate=12 December 2013}} == Activities == Most of the events were held at the [[Université des sciences et de la technologie Houari-Boumediene]]. Political themes of the conferences included peace, security, international co-operation; self-determination, sovereignty, national liberation, solidarity; democracy; development and the environment; employment; education, science, and technology; childhood; women; health; communication and culture; racism, neo-fascism and discrimination; youth's movements; the students' movement; human and peoples' rights. The Festival aimed to be an open forum for young people to exchange experiences, work together for alternative solutions, and establish joint programs of action on a wide range issues. Topics of discussion and themes of debates included disarmament and building a nuclear-free world, the "New World Order" and NATO, as well as neo-liberal globalisation. One day of the festival was devoted to solidarity with the people of Puerto Rico, especially the fight to get the U.S. Navy out of the island of [[Vieques]], which was then being used as a bombing range and testing ground by the navy and United States Navy in Vieques, Puerto Rico. A combined forum in solidarity with the struggles of the people of Cuba, Puerto Rico, Venezuela, and Colombia also took place. The panel included María Pili Hernández, representing the youth of the Fifth Republic Movement of Venezuela, the party founded by Hugo Chávez. She described changes in Venezuela's constitution and other measures by the Chávez government as an alternative example, a "third road," in the fight against imperialism. Also discussed were questions like the eradication of racism, gender equality, HIV/AIDS and drug abuse. For example, the event featured a joint WFDY - UNESCO Conference on "the Role of Young Women in promoting culture of peace in Africa". The festival also took place on the occasion of the 35th anniversary of the founding of the Organization of Caribbean and Latin American Students (OCLAE), who noted that the student federations represented in OCLAE and at the 15th world youth festival are part of an emerging anti-imperialist youth movement that is revitalizing the organization. Cultural activities at the festival included a series of amateur tournaments, including football, basketball, handball, a wheelchair competition, a chess match, tennis and table tennis. A series of festivals were also held including of political song, modern music, dance and mime, traditional folklore, and of film-makers. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.wfdy.org World Federation of Democratic Youth] * [http://pd.cpim.org/2001/sept09/sept092k1_wfys.htm Final Declaration of the 15th WFYS] {{WFYS editions}} {{DEFAULTSORT:World Festival Of Youth And Students}} [[Category:World Festival of Youth and Students]] [[Category:2001 conferences]] [[Category:Festivals in Algeria]] [[Category:21st century in Algiers]] [[Category:2001 in Algeria]] [[Category:Sports festivals in Africa]]

{{Year box}} '''1921 in sports''' describes the year’s events in world sport. ==[[American football]]== * [[1921 Chicago Staleys season|Chicago Staleys]] (later the Chicago Bears) win the 1921 [[American Professional Football Association]] title, albeit [[Staley Swindle|not without dispute]]. The APFA will eventually become the [[National Football League]]. * [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]] (1920 season): ** The [[California Golden Bears]] won 21-0 over the [[Ohio State Buckeyes]] to win the college football national championship * [[Cornell Big Red]] – [[college football]] national championship * 8 October — the first radio broadcast of a college game takes place between [[1921 West Virginia vs. Pittsburgh football game|West Virginia and Pittsburgh]] ==[[Association football]]== '''Brazil''' *[[Cruzeiro Esporte Clube|Cruzeiro of Belo Horizonte]], officially founded on January 2.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} '''England''' * [[1920–21 Football League|The Football League]] – [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] 59 points, [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] 54, [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] 52, [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] 51, [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] 50, [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] 47 * [[1921 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Tottenham Hotspur]] 1–0 [[Wolverhampton Wanderers]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], London * The Football League is expanded by the conversion of the [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] (founded in 1920) into the [[Football League Third Division South|Third Division South]] (D3S: 22 clubs) and the creation of the [[Football League Third Division North|Third Division North]] (D3N: 20 clubs). This brings the total number of League clubs to 86. Existing league clubs in D3N are [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] (relegated from the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]]) and [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]] (transferred from the former Third Division). New league members in D3N are: [[Accrington Stanley F.C. (1891)|Accrington Stanley]] (1921–1961), [[Ashington A.F.C.|Ashington]] (1921–1929), [[Barrow A.F.C.|Barrow]] (1921–1972), [[Chesterfield F.C.|Chesterfield]], [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]], [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]], [[Durham City F.C.|Durham City]] (1921–1928), [[Halifax Town A.F.C.|Halifax Town]], [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]], [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]], [[Nelson F.C.|Nelson]] (1921–1931), [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]], [[Southport F.C.|Southport]] (1921–1978), [[Stalybridge Celtic F.C.|Stalybridge Celtic]] (1921–1923), [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]], [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]], [[Wigan Borough F.C.|Wigan Borough]] (1921–1931) and [[Wrexham A.F.C.|Wrexham]]. * Apart from Grimsby Town (now in D3N) and [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] (promoted to the Second Division), all the remaining members of the former Third Division are transferred to D3S. Two new clubs are elected to this division: [[Aberdare Athletic F.C.|Aberdare Athletic]] (1921–1927) and [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]. '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – [[FC Nuremberg]] 5–0 [[Berliner FC Vorwärts 1890]] at Düsseldorf '''Republic of Ireland''' * Formation of the [[Football Association of Ireland]] (FAI). It applies solely to the Republic of Ireland and is not to be confused with the [[Irish Football Association]] (IFA), which is now the organising body for football in Northern Ireland only. The split in Irish football governance is not reflected in other sports such as [[cricket]] and [[rugby union]], in which [[Cricket Ireland]] and the [[Irish Rugby Football Union]] administer both countries. ==[[Track and field athletics|Athletics]]== '''Men's 100 metres''' * [[Charlie Paddock]] (USA) breaks the world record by running a time of 10.4 at [[Redlands, California]]. '''Lithuania''' * Officially established [[Lithuanian Athletics Championships]]. '''Monaco''' * [[1921 Women's World Games|first Women’s Olympiad]] in Monte Carlo ==[[Australian rules football]]== * 30 June – [[North Melbourne Football Club|North Melbourne]] disbands in an attempt to merge with VFL club [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] and is disqualified from the rest of [[1921 VFA season|the VFA season]]; the merger is precluded by a veto by the government of Essendon moving to [[Arden Street Oval|Arden Street]]. '''[[1921 VFL season|VFL Premiership]]''' * [[Richmond Football Club|Richmond]] wins the 25th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership, defeating [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] 5.6 (36) to 4.8 (32) [[1921 VFL Grand Final|in the Grand Final]] '''[[South Australian National Football League|South Australian Football League]]''' * 7 May – [[Glenelg Football Club|Glenelg]] become the SAFL’s eighth club when they play their first match against [[West Adelaide Football Club|West Adelaide]], losing 6.5 (41) to 18.10 (118). * 8 October – [[Port Adelaide Football Club (SANFL)|Port Adelaide]] 4.8 (32) defeat [[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]] 3.6 (24) for their ninth SAFL premiership. * [[Magarey Medal]] won by [[Dan Moriarty (Australian rules footballer born 1895)|Dan Moriarty]] (South Adelaide), [[Charlie Adams (Australian footballer)|Charlie Adams]]{{ref label|restropective1|a|a}} (Port Adelaide), [[John Karney]]{{ref label|restropective1|a|a}} (West Torrens) and [[Walter Scott (Australian footballer)|Walter Scott]]{{ref label|restropective1|a|a}} (Norwood) '''West Australian Football League''' * 1 October – [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] 5.9 (39) defeats [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 4.8 (32) to win its third consecutive premiership. * The inaugural [[Sandover Medal]] is won by [[Tom Outridge, Sr.]] ([[Subiaco Football Club|Subiaco]]), and posthumously awarded retrospectively{{ref label|restropective2|b|b}} to [[Cyril Hoft]] ([[Perth Football Club|Perth]]). ==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Swedish bandy champions|Championship final]] – [[IK Sirius]] 5–2 [[IFK Uppsala Bandy|IFK Uppsala]] (replay following 2–2 draw) ==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 5–13 October — [[1921 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] (NL) defeats [[1921 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]] (AL) to win the [[1921 World Series]] by 5 games to 3 '''Major League Baseball''' * [[Babe Ruth]] hits 59 [[home run]]s for the [[1921 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]], establishing a new single-season record for the third consecutive year '''Negro League Baseball''' * The [[Chicago American Giants]] win their second consecutive [[Negro National League (the first)|Negro National League]] pennant ==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 2 July — boxing’s first “million dollar gate” occurs when [[Jack Dempsey]] meets [[Georges Carpentier]] in a “hastily assembled outdoor arena built on a farm in [[Jersey City]], [[New Jersey]]”. A crowd of more than 80,000 attends an event billed by its promoter [[Tex Rickard]] as the "Battle of the Century". Dempsey wins by a fourth round knockout in a scheduled 12-round fight which is also special for its radio broadcast. It is the first-ever broadcast to a "mass audience" with ringside commentary relayed over the new [[radiophone]] to hundreds of thousands of people in the northeastern United States.[http://www.pophistorydig.com/?p=581 The Pop History Dig – Dempsey v. Carpentier]. Retrieved on 28 November 2009. * [[Pete Herman|Pete “Kid” Herman]] regains the [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship but is beaten soon afterwards by new champion [[Johnny Buff]]. '''Lineal world champions'''[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone] * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Dempsey]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Georges Carpentier]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Wilson (boxer)|Johnny Wilson]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Britton]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Benny Leonard]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Kilbane]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Joe Lynch (boxer)|Joe Lynch]] → [[Pete Herman|Pete "Kid" Herman]] → [[Johnny Buff]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Wilde]] ==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * [[9th Grey Cup]] in the [[Canadian Football League]] – [[Toronto Argonauts]] 23–0 [[Edmonton Eskimos]] ==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[England national cricket team|England]] tours Australia and becomes the first team to lose every match in a five-match [[Test cricket|Test series]]. In the [[1921 English cricket season|1921 English season]], [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] emphasises the post-war superiority that it owes, in particular, to the pace duo of [[Jack Gregory (cricketer)|Jack Gregory]] and [[Ted McDonald]]. Having won 5–0 in Australia the previous winter, the Australians win the first three Tests of the 1921 tour and then draw the last two. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Middlesex County Cricket Club|Middlesex]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Staffordshire County Cricket Club|Staffordshire]] * Most runs – [[Phil Mead]] 3179 @ 69.10 (HS 280*) * Most wickets – [[Alec Kennedy]] 186 @ 21.55 (BB 8–11) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Hubert Ashton]], [[Jack Bryan]], [[Jack Gregory (cricketer)|Jack Gregory]], [[Charlie Macartney]], [[Ted McDonald]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] * Most runs – [[Patsy Hendren]] 1178 @ 62.00 (HS 271) * Most wickets – [[Arthur Mailey]] 81 @ 22.53 (BB 9–121) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] and [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]] (shared) '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Wellington cricket team|Wellington]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – [[Western Province cricket team|Western Province]] '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – unfinished ==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[Léon Scieur]] (Belgium) wins the 15th [[1921 Tour de France|Tour de France]] '''Giro d'Italia''' * [[Giovanni Brunero]] of Legnano wins the ninth [[1921 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]] ==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * The championships are not held in 1921 ==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1921 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Jock Hutchison]] * [[1921 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Jim Barnes]] * [[1921 PGA Championship|USPGA Championship]] – [[Walter Hagen]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Willie Hunter (golfer)|Willie Hunter]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Jesse P. Guilford]] ==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1921 Grand National|Grand National]] – Shaun Spadah * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Bettina (horse)|Bettina]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Craig an Eran]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Humorist (horse)|Humorist]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Love in Idleness (horse)|Love in Idleness]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Polemarch (horse)|Polemarch]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Sister Olive '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Herendesy '''France''' * [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] – [[Ksar (horse)|Ksar]] '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Bohernore * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Ballyheron '''USA''' * [[1921 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Behave Yourself * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Broomspun * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Grey Lag ==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * [[Ottawa Senators (original)|Ottawa Senators]] defeats [[1920–21 Toronto St. Patricks season|Toronto St. Patricks]] to win the [[National Hockey League|NHL]] championship. * [[Vancouver Millionaires]] defeats [[Seattle Metropolitans]] in a two–game total–goal series 1–3, 6–0 (7–3) to win the [[Pacific Coast Hockey Association|PCHA]] championship. * 21 March – 4 April — Ottawa Senators defeats Vancouver Millionaires in the [[1921 Stanley Cup Finals]] by 3 games to 2 ==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1921 in motorsport|List of 1921 motorsport champions}} ==[[Multi-sport event]]s== '''Far Eastern Championship Games''' * Fifth [[1921 Far Eastern Championship Games|Far Eastern Championship Games]] held in [[Shanghai]]. '''Women's World Games''' * The [[1921 Women's Olympiad]] begins in Monte Carlo, first international [[women's sports]] event ==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 30 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 73rd [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] ==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Hull F.C.|Hull]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Leigh Centurions|Leigh]] 13–0 [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] at [[Wheater's Field]], [[Broughton, Salford|Broughton]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Broughton Rangers]] 6–3 [[Leigh Centurions|Leigh]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Hull Kingston Rovers]] 2–0 [[Hull F.C.|Hull]] '''Australia''' * [[1921 NSWRFL season|NSW Premiership]] – [[North Sydney Bears|North Sydney]] (outright winner) ==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * 34th [[1921 Five Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[England national rugby union team|England]] who complete the [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]] ==[[Shooting sports|Shooting]]== '''Germany''' *National championship won by Mr. Janich firing an [[Ortgies 7.65 mm Semi-Automatic Pistol|Ortgies]] semi-automatic pistol.[http://ortgies.net/ortgies0015.htm Koelliker, Donald W., "Ortgies: A Well-Known but Little Studied German Armsmaker of the Early Post-War Years," ''Gun Collector's Digest'' 1981, accessed April 19, 2010] ==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * not contested ==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Rhys Gemmell]] (Australia) defeats [[Alf Hedeman]] (Australia) 7–5 6–1 6–4 '''England''' * [[The Championships Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Bill Tilden]] (USA) defeats [[Brian Norton]] (South Africa) 4–6 2–6 6–1 6–0 7–5 * [[The Championships Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Suzanne Lenglen]] (France) defeats [[Elizabeth Ryan]] (USA) 6–2, 6–0 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Jean Samazeuilh]] (France) defeats [[André Gobert]] (France) 6–3 6–3 2–6 7–5 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Suzanne Lenglen]] (France) defeats [[Germaine Golding]] (France) by a walkover '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Bill Tilden]] (USA) defeats [[Bill Johnston (tennis player)|Bill Johnston]] (USA) 6–1 1–6 7–5 5–7 6–3 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Molla Bjurstedt Mallory]] (Norway) defeats [[Mary Browne]] (USA) 4–6 6–4 6–2 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1921 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|USA|1912}} 5–0 {{davis|JPN}} at [[West Side Tennis Club]] (grass) [[New York City]], [[United States]] ==Notes== {{note label|restropective1|a|a}}Awarded retrospectively by the SANFL in 1998.

{{NHLTeamSeason |League=NHL |Season=2001–02 |year=2001 |Team=Columbus Blue Jackets |Conference=[[Western Conference (NHL)|Western]] |ConferenceRank=15th |Division=[[Central Division (NHL)|Central]] |DivisionRank=5th |Record=22–47–8–5 |HomeRecord=14–18–5–4 |RoadRecord=8–29–3–1 |GoalsFor=164 |GoalsAgainst=255 |GeneralManager=[[Doug MacLean]] |Coach=[[Dave King (ice hockey)|Dave King]] |Captain=[[Lyle Odelein]] (Oct-Mar)
''Vacant'' (Mar-Apr) |AltCaptain= |Arena=[[Nationwide Arena]] |Attendance=18,136 |GoalsLeader=[[Ray Whitney (ice hockey)|Ray Whitney]] (21) |AssistsLeader=Ray Whitney (40) |PointsLeader=Ray Whitney (61) |PlusMinusLeader= |PIMLeader=[[Jody Shelley]] (206) |WinsLeader=[[Ron Tugnutt]] (12) |GAALeader=Ron Tugnutt (2.85) }} The '''[[2001–02 NHL season|2001–02]] [[Columbus Blue Jackets]] [[season (sports)|season]]''' was the Blue Jackets' [[list of Columbus Blue Jackets seasons|second]] [[Season (sports)|season]] in the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL), as the team was coming off a 28–39–9–6 record in their expansion season, earning 71 points and missing the [[2001 Stanley Cup playoffs|2001]] [[Stanley Cup playoffs]]. {{TOClimit|limit=2}} ==Regular season== Columbus would get off to a poor start, winning only one out of 13 games to open the season and falling to last place in the [[Western Conference (NHL)|Western Conference]]. While the Blue Jackets would play better as the season progressed, they were far off from playoff qualification and would eventually trade team captain [[Lyle Odelein]] to the [[Chicago Blackhawks]] in exchange for defenseman [[Jaroslav Špaček|Jaroslav Spacek]] at the [[NHL trade deadline|trade deadline]]. Columbus would finish the season with a 22–47–8–5 record, earning 57 points, which was 14 fewer points than in their previous season, and 37 points behind the [[Vancouver Canucks]] for the eighth final playoff spot in the West. Columbus would score an NHL-low 164 goals, and their 255 goals against was the highest total in the Western Conference, third-highest in the NHL. The 57 points the Jackets earned was the second fewest in the League, only ahead of the [[Atlanta Thrashers]], who finished with 54. [[Ray Whitney (ice hockey)|Ray Whitney]] would lead Columbus offensively, scoring a team-high 21 goals and 40 assists for 61 points, which broke the team record for points in a season. [[Mike Sillinger]] would be the only other Blue Jacket to score 20 goals, scoring 20 and adding 23 assists for 43 points. [[Deron Quint]] led the Jackets defense, earning 25 points, while [[Rostislav Klesla]] scored eight goals and earned 16 points in his first full season in the League. [[Jody Shelley]] had a team-high and club-record 206 penalty minutes in only 52 games. In goal, [[Ron Tugnutt]] and [[Marc Denis]] would split time, with Tugnutt winning a team-high 12 games and posting a team-best 2.85 [[goals against average]] (GAA). Tragedy struck at [[Nationwide Arena]] during a game on March 16, 2002, against the [[Calgary Flames]], when a shot by Jackets forward [[Espen Knutsen]] was deflected off the stick of Flames defenceman [[Derek Morris (ice hockey)|Derek Morris]] and sailed into the stands, hitting 13-year-old [[Brittanie Cecil]] in the head. Cecil would pass away on March 18 due to the injury. The Blue Jackets would finish the season 30th in the League in scoring, with 164 goals for, and would be shut out an NHL-high 11 times.https://www.hockey-reference.com/leagues/NHL_2002.htmlhttps://www.hockey-reference.com/leagues/NHL_2002_games.html ===Season standings=== {{2001–02 NHL Central Division standings|team=CLB}} {{Infobox national hockey team | Name = Brazil | Badge = | Badge_size = | caption = | Nickname = Yellow Eagles
(''Águias Amarelas'') | Association = [[Brazilian Ice Sports Federation|Confederação Brasileira de Desportos no Gelo]] | General Manager = | Coach = Jens Hinderlie | Asst Coach = Michael Christian Duc
Alexandre Capelle Jr. | Captain = | Most games = Julio Baptista &
João Gonçalves (11) | Top scorer = | Most points = Bruno Gomes (22) | Home Stadium = | IIHF code = BRA | IIHF Rank = | IIHF max = | IIHF max date = | IIHF min = | IIHF min date = | Team_Colors = {{color box|#00c000|border=darkgray}} {{color box|#ffef00|border=darkgray}} {{color box|#0000c0|border=darkgray}} {{color box|white|border=darkgray}} | Jerseys = | First game = {{ih|MEX}} 16–0 '''Brazil''' {{flagdeco|BRA}}
([[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]]; 2 March 2014) | Largest win = {{flagdeco|BRA}} '''Brazil''' 13–0 {{ih-rt|ARG}}
([[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]]; 11 June 2017) | Largest loss = {{ih|MEX}} 16–0 '''Brazil''' {{flagdeco|BRA}}
([[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]]; 2 March 2014) | World champ apps = | World champ first = | World champ best = | Regional name = [[Pan American Ice Hockey Tournament]] | Regional cup apps = 4 | Regional cup first = [[2014 Pan American Ice Hockey Tournament|2014]] | Regional cup best = [[File:Bronze medal with cup.svg|16px]] 3rd ([[2015 Pan American Ice Hockey Tournament|2015]]) | Record = 3–8–1 }} The '''Brazilian national ice hockey team''' ({{lang-pt|Seleção Brasileira de Hóquei no Gelo}}) is the national men's [[ice hockey]] team of [[Brazil]]. The team is controlled by the [[Brazilian Ice Sports Federation]] and as an associate member of the [[International Ice Hockey Federation]] (IIHF). Brazil is currently not ranked in the [[IIHF World Ranking]] and has still not actively competing in any [[Ice Hockey World Championships|World Championship]], but have played in the [[Pan American Ice Hockey Tournament|Pan American Tournament]], a regional tournament for lower-tier hockey nations in the [[Americas]]. ==History== ===Ice hockey in Brazil=== Brazil joined the IIHF on 26 June 1984. It was the first [[South America]]n nation to join the IIHF until [[Argentina men's national ice hockey team|Argentina]] joined in 1998 and [[Chile national ice hockey team|Chile]] in 2000. Brazil has still not actively competing in any World Championship in ice hockey, except in [[Roller in-line hockey|inline hockey]]. There are a number of rinks around the country. The teams that competed for the 2009–10 [[Brazilian Ice Hockey Championship|National Championship]] are Sociedade Hipica Campinas, Sertãozinho, Amparo NL, Palmeiras, Darks-Guariani, Portuguesa and Capelle Hockey School. [[Mike Greenlay]] and [[Robyn Regehr]], who both played in the [[National Hockey League|NHL]], were born in Brazil. ===Participation in IIHF competitions=== Brazil participated in the [[2014 Pan American Ice Hockey Tournament]]. They played their first international game against the host nation, [[Mexico men's national ice hockey team|Mexico]], which they lost 16–0. In the following game, Brazil recorded its first international goal in a 5–3 defeat to Argentina.{{cite web | url = http://www.eurohockey.com/game/detail/76202-brazil--argentina.html | title = Brazil vs. Argentina | publisher = Euro Hockey | date = | accessdate = 2015-06-08 }} In the [[2015 Pan American Ice Hockey Tournament|2015 edition]], Brazil recorded its first win in its first game in the tournament, 5–2, against a junior [[Mexico men's national under-18 ice hockey team|Mexico]] team.{{cite web | url = http://thehockeyhouse.net/international-hockey/brazil-records-first-ever-hockey-victory-in-5-2-victory-over-mexico/ | title = Brazil records first ever hockey victory in 5-2 victory over Mexico | publisher = The Hockey House | date = | accessdate = 2015-06-08 }} After beating Argentina “B” (7–0) and losing to [[Colombia men's national ice hockey team|Colombia]] (3–0) and Mexico (11–1), Brazil won its last game by 6–1 against Argentina's main team on 7 June, and reached third place in standings, thus winning the bronze medal, its first in the tournament.{{cite web | url = http://thehockeyhouse.net/international-hockey/brazil-wins-first-ever-ice-hockey-medal-at-pan-american-games/ | title = Brazil Wins First Ever Ice Hockey Medal at Pan-American Games | publisher = The page.title: Cambodia at the 2009 Southeast Asian Games

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox country at games | NOC = CAM | NOCname = [[National Olympic Committee of Cambodia]] | oldcode = | year = 2009 | date = | games = Southeast Asian Games | location = [[Vientiane]] | competitors = | sports = | flagbearer = Sok Chanmean (Pétanque) | officials = | gold = 3 | silver = 10 | bronze = 27 | rank = 9 | appearances = * 1977–1981 * [[Cambodia at the 1983 Southeast Asian Games|1983]] * [[Cambodia at the 1985 Southeast Asian Games|1985]] * [[Cambodia at the 1987 Southeast Asian Games|1987]] * 1989–1993 * [[Cambodia at the 1995 Southeast Asian Games|1995]] * [[Cambodia at the 1997 Southeast Asian Games|1997]] * [[Cambodia at the 1999 Southeast Asian Games|1999]] * [[Cambodia at the 2001 Southeast Asian Games|2001]] * [[Cambodia at the 2003 Southeast Asian Games|2003]] * [[Cambodia at the 2005 Southeast Asian Games|2005]] * [[Cambodia at the 2007 Southeast Asian Games|2007]] * 2009 * [[Cambodia at the 2011 Southeast Asian Games|2011]] * [[Cambodia at the 2013 Southeast Asian Games|2013]] * [[Cambodia at the 2015 Southeast Asian Games|2015]] | seealso = | website = {{URL|http://www.noccambodia.org/website/?lang=en}} }} Cambodia competed in the [[2009 Southeast Asian Games]] athletics tournament, winning three gold medals and 40 medals in total. == Preparations == Cambodia only announced the formation of its National Team Organizing Committee for the SEA Games in mid-October 2009,[http://balita.ph/2009/10/16/cambodia-launches-committee-to-prepare-for-sea-games Xinhua, Cambodia launches committee to prepare for SEA Games] less than two months ahead of the start of the Games in [[Vientiane]], [[Laos]]. The [[National Olympic Committee of Cambodia]] (NOCC) assigned its Vice President [[Bun Sok]] to chair this committee. This committee was made up of representatives of various Olympic sports federations and was responsible for final screening and selection of [[sportsperson|athlete]]s to represent Cambodia in various sports. Cambodia was to compete in 17 sports, with expectations of medals in [[pétanque]], [[athletics (sport)|athletics]], [[tennis]], [[wrestling]], [[boxing]], [[taekwondo]] and [[beach volleyball]]. As part of the preparation for 2009 SEA Games, the athletics and taekwondo athletes traveled to [[South Korea]] to undergo intensive training courtesy of the [[Incheon City of Korea Support Program]], while other athletes were to complete training in [[Vietnam]]. The [[Phnom Penh Post]] reported that, according to [[Nhan Sokvisal]], the SEA Games coordinator, Cambodia was looking forward and optimistic to better their medals haul from the last [[SEA Games]] in [[Thailand]] in 2007. In the 2007 Games, Cambodia won 19 metals - two gold, five silver and 12 bronze. Cambodian Prime Minister [[Hun Sen]] confirmed his presence at the Opening Ceremony after Laotian Prime Minister [[Bouasone Bouphavanh]]'s visit to Cambodia in late November.[http://www.phnompenhpost.com/index.php/2009112629765/Sport/briefs-pm-to-attend-sea-games.html PP Post, Briefs: PM to attend SEA Games ] ==Medalists== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:100%" |- ! width="100"|Medal ! width="250"|Name ! width="175"|Sport ! width="250"|Event |- | {{gold medal}} | Sok Chanmean | [[Pétanque at the 2009 Southeast Asian Games|Pétanque]] | Men's Single |- | {{gold medal}} | Heng Than | Pétanque | Men's Precision Shooting |- | {{gold medal}} | Chov Sotheara | [[Wrestling at the 2009 Southeast Asian Games|Wrestling]] | Women's <45 kg |- | {{silver medal}} | Phal Sophat | [[Boxing at the 2009 Southeast Asian Games|Boxing]] | Men's Feather Weight - 57 Kg |- | {{silver medal}} | Chhoy Bouthorn | [[Taekwondo at the 2009 Southeast Asian Games|Taekwondo]] | Men's 58 kg |- | {{silver medal}} | So Naro | Taekwondo | Men's 87 kg |- | {{silver medal}} | Seon Elit | Taekwondo | Men's >87 kg |- | {{silver medal}} | Ouk Sreymom | Pétanque | Women's Single |- | {{silver medal}} | Duong Dina

revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | stadium_name= Canvas Stadium | image= SLF@CSS, west stands construction, 10-18-16.jpg | image_size = 220 | caption = Under construction in 2016 | location = [[Fort Collins, Colorado]] | owner = [[Colorado State University]] | operator = {{nowrap|Colorado State University}} | coordinates = {{coord|40.5700|-105.0885|format=dms|type:landmark_region:US-CO|display=it}} | pushpin_map = USA#Colorado | pushpin_relief = 1 | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = Location in the United States and Colorado | broke_ground = September 14, 2015{{cite news|url=http://www.coloradoan.com/story/news/2015/09/12/colorado-state-university-stadium-groundbreaking/72163352/ |title=CSU breaks ground on new football stadium |first=Rob |last=White |newspaper=[[Fort Collins Coloradoan|Coloradoan]] |location=(Fort Collins) |date=September 12, 2015 |accessdate=September 14, 2015}} | opened = August 5, 2017{{cite web|url=http://stadium.colostate.edu/faqs/ |title=Colorado State Stadium: Frequently Asked Questions |publisher=Colorado State University |accessdate=March 27, 2017}} | surface = Shaw Sports [[Artificial turf]] | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]220.1 million{{cite web|url=http://stadium.colostate.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/May-2016-Stadium-Report.pdf |title=CSU’s Multi-Purpose Stadium Report – May 2016 |publisher=Colorado State University |accessdate=July 22, 2016}} | architect = [[Populous (company)|Populous]]
ICON Venue Group | general_contractor = M. A. Mortenson Co. | tenants = [[Colorado State Rams football|Colorado State Rams]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (2017–present) | seating_capacity = 41,000 | former_names = Sonny Lubick Field at Colorado State Stadium (2017) }} '''Canvas Stadium,''' also known as '''Sonny Lubick Field at Canvas Stadium''', is an outdoor [[college football]] stadium in the [[Western United States|western]] [[United States]], on the campus of [[Colorado State University]] in [[Fort Collins, Colorado]]. It is the home field of the [[Colorado State Rams football|CSU Rams]] of the [[Mountain West Conference]]; it opened August 5, [[2017 Colorado State Rams football team|2017]], and hosted its first game on August 26. It replaced [[Sonny Lubick Field at Hughes Stadium]], which had been the Rams' home since 1968. The stadium sits about 1 mile (5,003 feet) above sea level. == Development == After a nearly two-year process including cost and financing changes, protests, community outreach, and an inter-governmental agreement with the city of Fort Collins, the $220 million, 41,000-capacity on-campus multi-purpose stadium began construction in May 2015. In 2013, the university began raising funds for a ~40,000-seat on-campus facility to replace Hughes Stadium. The project was partially driven by major decreases in state funding for CSU in recent decades. As a result, CSU has been seeking to draw more out-of-state students, whose current tuition is three times that of Colorado residents. CSU president [[Anthony A. Frank]] included the new stadium as part of this goal saying "the new facility will help build a winning football team while advancing one of the school's highest priorities: attracting more out-of-state students".{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303983904579093432304563144?ru=yahoo?mod=yahoo_itp |title=Colorado State University Bets on a Stadium to Fill Its Coffers |first=Rachel |last=Bachman |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |date=September 27, 2013 |accessdate=September 28, 2013}} According to ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'',
"Skeptics, including some alumni and faculty, see the project as a boondoggle—especially for a team that plays in a relatively low-profile athletic conference and doesn't sell out its current 32,500-seat stadium off campus. The debate has sparked dueling websites, animated letters to the editor and arguments about the role of sports at a university."
Many community members expressed frustration that they did not feel they were being heard at the [[Colorado State University|CSU]] [[Board of governors|Board of Governors]] meeting when final approval was given. After the vote Board chair, Dorothy Horrell, thanked those making comments for their input and reiterated her feeling that
"the decision to build an on-campus stadium was made after "thoughtful and thorough examination of this issue" that is reflected in the board's records. "As my parents used to tell me, just because I ask a question and didn't get the answer I wanted, it isn't that the question wasn't answered," Horrell said. "And I would just remind us all of that."{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.coloradoan.com/story/news/local/2015/05/07/colorado-state-stadium-board-governors-athletic-director/70964618/ |title=CSU AD pledges to heal wounds opened in stadium debate |website=Coloradoan.com |date=2015-05-07 |accessdate=2016-05-05}}
The new stadium, initially estimated to cost $246 million, was originally only to be built if $125 million in private funds had been raised by October 2014. Plans were put on hold after fundraising support for the project failed to materialize as expected, according to a September 26, 2014, story in the ''Denver Business Journal''. On November 29, 2014, Frank sent a memo to the school's board of governors recommending that the new stadium be approved without raising the 50% cost in public funds as previously planned. The memo estimated that a 35,900-seat facility would cost $195 million; building with a capacity of 41,200 would cost $220 million.{{cite news |url=http://www.therepublic.com/view/story/8d99378428ea4277a35afc5556b35237/FBC--Colorado-St-Stadium |title=Colorado State president recommends new on-campus stadium to replace existing football arena |agency=[[Associated Press]] |newspaper=[[The Republic (Columbus, Indiana)|The Republic]] |location=[[Columbus, Indiana]] |date=November 29, 2014 |accessdate=December 6, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141219072022/http://www.therepublic.com/view/story/8d99378428ea4277a35afc5556b35237/FBC--Colorado-St-Stadium# |archive-date=2014-12-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Frank also estimated that renovating Hughes Stadium to last 30 to 40 years would cost a minimum of $149 million. The board of governors approved a new on campus multi-purpose stadium on December 5, 2014. At that time ''NBCSports.com'' writer Brent Sobleski speculated that the hiring of Rams head coach [[Jim McElwain]] for the head coaching vacancy at [[Florida Gators football|Florida]] days earlier may have swayed the board, noting, "An improving program and a new stadium could help lure another top-level candidate like the school previously did when McElwain was initially hired."{{cite news|url=http://collegefootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/12/05/board-of-regents-approve-new-on-campus-stadium-for-colorado-state-rams/related/ |title=Board of Governors approve new on-campus stadium for Colorado State Rams |first=Brent |last=Sobleski |work=College Football Talk |publisher=''NBCSports.com'' |date=December 5, 2014 |accessdate=December 6, 2014}} CSU went on to hire Mike Bobo from the SEC like McElwain before him. University of Georgia's Coach Bobo was named the nation's Offensive Coordinator of the Year in 2013 by 247Sports.com.{{cite web|url=http://m.ajc.com/weblogs/uga-sports/2013/dec/19/georgias-mike-bobo-named-offensive-coordinator-yea/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=May 24, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150525015254/http://m.ajc.com/weblogs/uga-sports/2013/dec/19/georgias-mike-bobo-named-offensive-coordinator-yea/ |archivedate=May 25, 2015 }} Georgia also had the top scoring offense in the SEC in 2014, Bobo's last season before heading to CSU.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/conferences/statistics/team/_/stat/total/sort/totalPointsPerGame/id/8/sec-conference |title=2015 SEC College Football Team Statistics Leaders for Total - ESPN |website=Espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=2016-05-05}} Construction of the new stadium, tentatively known as Colorado State Stadium, began in May 2015; the official groundbreaking ceremony was held the weekend of CSU's September 12, 2015 home football game against [[2015 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]]. The first game in the new stadium was August 26, 2017, when the Rams defeated [[2017 Oregon State Beavers football team|Oregon State]] 58-27.{{cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/college-football/recap?gameId=400935282 |title=Colorado St. opens new stadium by beating Oregon St 58-27 |agency=Associated Press |publisher=''ESPN.com'' |date=August 26, 2017 |accessdate=August 27, 2017}} == Stadium donations == In March 2016, the university announced that it had received an anonymous gift of $20 million over a 30-year period with the express purpose of naming the playing field at the new stadium after former Rams head coach [[Sonny Lubick]], whose name was also attached to the playing field at Hughes Stadium.{{cite press release|url=http://www.csurams.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/032516aac.html |title=$20 million gift ensures winning tradition of "Sonny Lubick Field" continues at CSU's new on-campus stadium |publisher=Colorado State Rams |date=March 25, 2016 |accessdate=July 22, 2016}} This gift was roughly the amount that the university had hoped to make by selling the naming rights to both the stadium and the field.{{cite news|url=https://www.coloradoan.com/story/sports/csu/football/2018/04/19/colorado-state-university-sells-naming-rights-campus-stadium-fort-collins/531368002/ |title=CSU's on-campus stadium naming rights sell for $37.7 million |first=Kelly |last=Lyell |newspaper=[[Fort Collins Coloradoan|Coloradoan]] |location=Fort Collins, CO |date=April 19, 2018 |accessdate=April 25, 2018}} In August of that year, [[New Belgium Brewing Company]], an iconic, local Fort Collins brewery, donated $4.3 million to put its name and its product on the party deck of the north end zone of the $220 million stadium.http://source.colostate.edu/csu-new-belgium-brewing-craft-agreement-creating-new-belgium-porch-at-on-campus-stadium New Belgium Brewing craft agreement creating New Belgium Porch at on-campus stadium This new bar area is called the New Belgium Porch. On April 19, 2018, CSU announced it had sold the naming rights of the stadium itself to Public Service Credit Union for $37.7 million over 15 years. The actual name was not revealed at that time because PSCU was in the process of adopting a new name, which was ultimately revealed on June 5 of that year as Canvas Credit Union. Accordingly, the stadium became Canvas Stadium.{{cite press release|url=http://csurams.com/news/2018/6/5/general-canvas-stadium-is-new-name-for-colorado-state-universitys-multipurpose-stadium.aspx |title=Canvas Stadium is new name for Colorado State University’s multipurpose stadium |publisher=Colorado State Rams |date=June 5, 2018 |accessdate=June 8, 2018}} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://stadium.colostate.edu/}} {{Colorado State Rams football navbox}} {{Colorado State University}} {{Mountain West Conference football venue navbox}} {{Colorado college football venues}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:Colorado State Rams football]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Larimer County, Colorado]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Larimer County, Colorado]] [[Category:American football venues in Colorado]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2017]] [[Category:2017 establishments in Colorado]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Central Stadium of Jonava | nickname = | image = [[File:JSC1.jpg|250px]] | fullname = Jonavos rajono savivaldybės kūno kultūros ir sporto centro centrinis stadionas | coordinates = {{Coord|55|04|41|N|24|16|17|E|region:LT_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | address = Žeimių g. 17 | location = [[Jonava]], [[Lithuania]] | broke_ground = | renovated = 2010 | demolished = | owner = [[Jonava|Jonava city municipality]] | operator = Physical culture and sports center of Jonava | surface = Grass and running tracks | construction_cost = | architect = | tenants = [[FK Jonava]]
[[FK Jonava B]] | seating_capacity = 1,008[http://www.lff.lt/lt/jonavos_kksc_stadionas] | dimensions = | acreage = 13 970 m² | pushpin_map = Lithuania Jonava | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = }} '''Central Stadium of Jonava''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Jonava]], [[Lithuania]]. It is currently the biggest stadium in the city. The seating capacity is going to be expanded to 3,000.[http://www.futbolinis.lt/content/stadium/16/lt www.futbolinis.lt] Near stadium is outdoor pond, which can be used for water events. == Events == The stadium hosts [[association football|football]] matches, regional athletics events, strength sports, etc. It also can host outdoor [[basketball]] and [[volleyball]] championships. The stadium also has hosted some cultural events{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}. == Equipment == *2 grass fields (mostly using for football) *Running tracks *6 street basketball squads *Rugby and volleyball equipment *Beach volleyball squad *Screen and lighting == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Central stadium of Jonava}} *[http://www.jonavakksc.lt/category/naujienos/ Official website] [[Category:Football venues in Lithuania|Jonava Central Stadium]] [[Category:Sports venues in Jonava]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Lithuania|Jonava Central Stadium]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Lithuania|Jonava Central Stadium]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Jonava]] {{Lithuania-sports-venue-stub}} {{Jonava-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | name = John Rose Minnesota Oval | nickname = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | fullname = | former names = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = | address = | location = [[Roseville, Minnesota|Roseville]], [[Minnesota]], [[United States]] | coordinates = | type = [[bandy rink|outdoor bandy rink]] | genre = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = {{start date|December 1993|df=y}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | production = | cost = | architect = | builder = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = | embedded = | website = | publictransit = }} {{More citations needed|date=June 2010}} The '''Guidant John Rose Minnesota Oval''', formerly the '''John Rose Minnesota Oval''', is an outdoor [[ice rink]] in [[Roseville, Minnesota|Roseville]], [[Minnesota]], [[United States]]. It is claimed to be the largest artificial outdoor [[ice skating|skating]] surface in North America.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} The facility was constructed from June to December 1993. ==Rink== The rink consists of a {{convert|110000|sqft|adj=on}} [[concrete]] surface (a 400-meter track surrounding an infield ice arena) with {{convert|84|mi}} of embedded cooling tubes and an 800-ton refrigeration system. When the temperature is above {{convert|50|F}}—the highest temperature at which an icy surface can be maintained—the concrete surface can be used for [[inline skating]]. ==History== The Oval had its beginnings in 1983, when then-governor [[Rudy Perpich]] dreamed of hosting the [[Olympic Games]]. As part of the bid preparation, a task force was formed to determine locations of new facilities. After years of local efforts, Roseville was selected. The city was awarded state bonding money for the design and construction of a multi-purpose outdoor skating facility, which opened in December 1993. The facility was named after [[John Rose (Minnesota politician)|John Rose]], a Roseville teacher and member of the [[Minnesota House of Representatives]].{{cite web | title = Skate the Oval | url = http://www.skatetheoval.com | accessdate = 2007-10-29}} The Guidant John Rose Minnesota Oval hosted the [[1995 Bandy World Championship]] for men and the [[2006 Women's Bandy World Championship]]. It has also hosted US Speedskating Championships, US Junior Speedskating Championships, American Cup Speedskating, World Cup Speedskating, National Bandy Championships, and Aggressive Skating Association competitions. The [[Minnesota Wild]] held their hockey jersey unveiling at the Oval, and notable visitors have included [[Dan Jansen]], [[Bonnie Blair]], [[Paul Wylie]], and [[Neal Broten]]. The facility is the main training site for the [[United States national bandy team]] and local hockey and speedskating clubs. Leaks in the cooling system were discovered in 2004, making the season's service uncertain. In June 2005, the [[Guidant|Guidant Foundation]] contributed $500,000 to allow for needed repairs to the facility's refrigeration system. The Oval's official name was changed in recognition of the Foundation's gift and continuing support. ==Events== The Oval hosts over 100,000 guests each year. Sporting events held there include [[bandy]], [[ice hockey]], [[speed skating]], and recreational ice skating. In summer the Oval becomes the largest skating park in the Midwest,{{cite web | title = Skate the Oval | url = http://www.skatetheoval.com/page/show/254558-guidant-john-rose-mn-oval| accessdate = 2013-03-13}} as ramps are put up for BMX biking, roller hockey, and [[Aggressive inline skating|aggressive skating]]. The track is used for inline skating, and a summer skateboard camp is held for beginning to intermediate skateboarders aged 6–13. I.S.I.-certified ice skating lessons are given by Roseville Skating School in the connected Roseville Ice Arena during the winter months.{{cite web | title = Skate the Oval | url = http://www.skatetheoval.com/page/show/254561-roseville-skating-lessons| accessdate = 2013-03-13}} The Oval also hosts two local speedskating clubs: the Greater Minnesota Speedskating Association and the Midway Speedskating Club. Midway Speedskating Club is a non-profit organization dedicated to developing speedskating skills in young skaters. It has produced Olympic athletes and coaches.{{cite web | title = Midway Speedskating | url = http://midwayspeedskating.org/news-and-events/| accessdate = 2013-03-13}} A novice speedskating program is put on by the Midway Speedskating Club through the Roseville Parks and Recreation Department for youth aged 4–14. February 25–27, 2015, the [[Bandy World Championship G-17|Bandy World Championship for girls up to 17]] was organised here.[http://www.rusbandy.ru/news/6702 Чемпионат мира среди девушек (U-17)] The [[2016 Women's Bandy World Championship]] will. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.cityofroseville.com/index.asp?NID=336 Official site] *[http://shingobee.com/community_rec.htm Shingobee: John Rose Minnesota Oval] *[http://www.skatetheoval.com Skate the Oval information site] *[http://www.speedskatingnews.info/?page_id=826&bahn=USRO John Rose Minnesota Oval Roseville] at www.speedskatingnews.info *[http://www.speedskatingstats.com/index.php?file=rinks&rink=roseville John Rose Minnesota Oval, Roseville] at www.speedskatingstats.com {{S-start}} {{S-sta|et}} {{Succession box| title=[[Bandy World Championship]]

{{refimprove|date=May 2008}} {{Infobox stadium | name = David S. Mack Sports and Exhibition Complex | nickname = "The Mack" | image = David S Mack Sports and Exhibition Complex 1.jpg | fullname = David S. Mack Sports and Exhibition Complex | former_names = | location = 245 North Hofstra Avenue
Hempstead, NY 11549 | coordinates = {{coord|40.719681|-73.596865|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = October 1998 | built = | opened = January 2, 2000 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Hofstra University]] | operator = [[Hofstra University]] | surface = Hardwood | construction_cost = $15 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|15000000|1999}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = StanMar Inc. | capacity = 5,023 | tenants = Hofstra Pride }} '''The David S. Mack Sports and Exhibition Complex,''' also known as Mack Sports Complex, or just "The Mack" for short, is a 5,023-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Town of Hempstead, New York|Hempstead, New York]]. The arena opened in 1999 and replaced the [[Physical Fitness Center]]. ==Basketball== It is home to the [[Hofstra University]] [[Hofstra Pride|Pride]] men's and women's [[basketball]] [[team]]s, as well as the nationally ranked Pride wrestling team. It hosted the 2000 and 2001 title games of the [[America East Conference]] men's basketball tournaments, and also hosted two Postseason NIT games in 2006 (against Nebraska of the Big Twelve, and Old Dominion of the CAA). In 2006, Hofstra Arena was renamed the 'David S. Mack Sports and Exhibition Complex'. Hofstra belongs to the CAA (Colonial Athletic Association). Before an overtime loss to [[Drexel University]] in February, the Pride had previously won 28 consecutive regular season home games at the Mack. The Mack was also home to the nation's second longest home win streak (behind [[Gonzaga University]]) in 2006, before the Pride's NIT Quarterfinals loss to [[Old Dominion University]]. Hofstra University Men's Basketball has developed an excellent fan base on Long Island, especially in [[Nassau County, New York|Nassau County]], as it continues to have winning seasons year after year. ==Other events== Hofstra Arena also hosts other events year round, such as college fairs, graduations and Kellenberg Memorial High School's Blue and Gold Sports Night. "The Mack" also hosted the final Presidential Debate of the 2008 U.S. Presidential election between Republican [[John McCain]] and Democrat [[Barack Obama]]{{cite news |title=Hofstra University Is Agog Over the Presidential Debate on Its Turf|first=Javier C.|last=Hernandez|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/15/nyregion/15hofstra.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 14, 2008|accessdate=January 8, 2010}} as well as the town hall format of the second Presidential Debate of the 2012 Presidential election between Republican [[Mitt Romney]] and incumbent President [[Barack Obama]]. On September 26, 2016, it hosted the first Presidential Debate of the 2016 election between Republican [[Donald Trump]] and Democrat [[Hillary Clinton]]. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.nmnathletics.com/ViewArticle.dbml?&DB_OEM_ID=22200&ATCLID=3713851 Mack Sports Complex - GoHofstra.com] {{Hofstra University}} {{Hofstra Pride men's basketball navbox}} {{Colonial Athletic Association basketball venue navbox}} [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Long Island]] [[Category:Basketball venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Hofstra Pride basketball]] [[Category:Sports venues in Hempstead, New York]] [[Category:Sports venues in Nassau County, New York]] [[Category:2000 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2000]] [[Category:College wrestling venues in the United States]] {{NewYork-sports-venue-stub}}

The '''Indonesia President Invitational''' was an [[Asian Tour]] [[golf]] tournament. It was played for the first time in October 2007 at the Bumi Serpong Damai Course in [[Indonesia]]. The Bumi Serpong Damai Course was designed by [[Jack Nicklaus]]. The tournament's main sponsor was [[Pertamina]] in 2007 and 2008. In 2009, the purse was US$400,000.
==Winners== '''Indonesia President Invitational ''' *2009 {{flagicon|IND}} [[Gaganjeet Bhullar]]

{{WNBA Awards}} The '''Kim Perrot Sportsmanship Award''' is an annual [[Women's National Basketball Association]] (WNBA) award given since the league's [[1997 WNBA season|inaugural season]], to the player who most "exemplifies the ideals of [[sportsmanship]] on the court—ethical behavior, fair play and integrity." This is the same criterion used by the analogous [[NBA Sportsmanship Award]], given by the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] since its [[1995–96 NBA season|1995–96 season]]. Every year, each of the WNBA teams nominates one of its players to compete for this award. From these nominees, a panel of sportswriters and broadcasters vote for first and second place winners of this award. First place selections receive two votes, while second place selections receive one. The player with the highest point total, regardless of the number of first-place votes, wins the award. Since the [[2000 WNBA season]], the award is named for the late [[Kim Perrot]], who helped guide the [[Houston Comets]] to their first two WNBA championships before she died in August, 1999, after suffering from [[cancer]] for seven-month. ==Winners== {{clear}} {{col-start}}{{col-break|width=1%}} {| class="navbox wikitable" style="width: 80%; text-align:center; font-size:90%" |- ! {{citation style|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = '''Kosmos''' | type = Sociedad Limitada | industry = Sports Investment | founded = 2017 | founders =[[Gerard Piqué]] (President)
[[Hiroshi Mikitani]]
Michael Evans
Nullah Sarker
Edmund Chu | hq_location_city = [[Barcelona]] | hq_location_country = [[Spain]] |parent = [[Kosmos Global Holdings|Kosmos]] |subsid = Kosmos Tennis | website = {{URL|www.kosmosholding.com}} }} '''Kosmos Global Holding S.L.''', also known as '''Kosmos Holding''' or '''Kosmos''', is a global sports and media investment group headquartered in Barcelona, Spain. Founded in 2017 by [[FC Barcelona]] and [[Spanish national football team]] player [[Gerard Piqué]], and his friends [[Hiroshi Mikitani]], chairman and CEO of [[Rakuten]], Michael Evans, Nullah Sarker, and Edmund Chu, .{{cite web|url=https://www.economiadigital.es/directivos-y-empresas/gerard-pique-monta-su-ultimo-negocio-con-sus-colegas-de-harvard_543422_102.html|title=Gerard Piqué monta su último negocio con dos 'colegas' de Harvard|website=Economiadigital (ed. general)|access-date=2018-08-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180704130939/https://www.economiadigital.es/directivos-y-empresas/gerard-pique-monta-su-ultimo-negocio-con-sus-colegas-de-harvard_543422_102.html|archive-date=2018-07-04|dead-url=no|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://worldfootballsummit.com/world-football-summit-transform-madrid-world-capital-football-industry/|title=WFS, ready to transform Madrid in the world capital of the football industry - World Football Summit|website=Worldfootballsummit.com|access-date=2018-09-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181113171751/https://worldfootballsummit.com/world-football-summit-transform-madrid-world-capital-football-industry/|archive-date=2018-11-13|dead-url=no|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://atlas.world/member/edmund-chu/|title=Edmund Chu - Atlas Network|website=Atlas.world|access-date=2018-09-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181113170204/https://atlas.world/member/edmund-chu/|archive-date=2018-11-13|dead-url=no|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.palco23.com/competiciones/pique-ficha-talento-de-wwp-y-asics-para-preparar-su-entrada-en-el-negocio-del-tenis.html|title=Piqué ficha talento de WWP y Asics para preparar su entrada en el negocio del tenis|website=Palco23.com|access-date=2018-09-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181113170237/https://www.palco23.com/competiciones/pique-ficha-talento-de-wwp-y-asics-para-preparar-su-entrada-en-el-negocio-del-tenis.html|archive-date=2018-11-13|dead-url=no|df=}} == Activities == On February 26, 2018, Kosmos announced plans to invest $3 billion over 25 years in the [[Davis Cup]] by [[BNP Paribas]]. Kosmos will partner with the [[International Tennis Federation]] to transform the tournament.{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/sports/report/major-davis-cup-shake-up-approved/20180816.htm|title=Major Davis Cup shake-up approved - Rediff.com Sports|website=Rediff.com|access-date=2018-09-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181113210351/http://www.rediff.com/sports/report/major-davis-cup-shake-up-approved/20180816.htm|archive-date=2018-11-13|dead-url=no|df=}} On August 6, 2018, [[Larry Ellison]] published a letter announcing that he will be joining Kosmos as an investor.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tennis-daviscup/ellison-excited-for-indian-wells-to-host-revamped-davis-cup-idUSKBN1KS12V|title=Ellison excited for Indian Wells to host revamped Davis Cup|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|website=Reuters.com|access-date=2018-08-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180808215746/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tennis-daviscup/ellison-excited-for-indian-wells-to-host-revamped-davis-cup-idUSKBN1KS12V|archive-date=2018-08-08|dead-url=no|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://eu.desertsun.com/story/sports/tennis/2018/08/06/larry-ellisons-help-could-davis-cup-make-its-way-indian-wells-tennis-world-cup-federer-nadal-serena/919947002/|title=With Larry Ellison's help, could Davis Cup make its way to Indian Wells?|website=Eu.desertsun.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tennispanorama.com/archives/63137|title=BNP Paribas Open Tournament Owner Larry Ellison Supports New Davis Cup Format - Tennis Panorama|date=6 August 2018|website=Tennispanorama.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.infocif.es/cargos-administrador/kosmos-global-holding-sl|title=Cargos y administradores de KOSMOS GLOBAL HOLDING SL B67112656|website=Infocif.es}}{{Excessive citations inline |date=November 2018}} Kosmos Tennis division is run by Javier Alonso former director of [[Dorna]] and Fernando Soler, the former head of [[IMG]] Tennis. Kosmos other activities in the sports space include the recent transfer documentary with Athletico Madrid forward, [[Antoine Griezmann]]. == Criticism of Davis Cup == Kosmos partnership with the International Tennis Federation to revamp the Davis Cup has been criticized by the tennis community. Many claim that the partnership will take away from the traditions of the 118-year-old tennis event.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/22595981/davis-cup-revamp-plans-hold-event-one-location-seven-days-november-get-mixed-response|title=Davis Cup revamp plans get mixed response|website=Espn.com|access-date=2018-08-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180523172112/http://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/22595981/davis-cup-revamp-plans-hold-event-one-location-seven-days-november-get-mixed-response|archive-date=2018-05-23|dead-url=no|df=}} In a secret meeting held in Orlando, Florida, on August 16, 2018, the changes proposed by Kosmos received a 71 percent approval at the International Tennis Federation annual general meeting. Proposals require a two-thirds majority to pass.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/16/sports/davis-cup-vote-itf.html|title=Davis Cup Overhaul Wins Approval From Tennis Officials|website=Nytimes.com|access-date=2018-08-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180817181723/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/16/sports/davis-cup-vote-itf.html|archive-date=2018-08-17|dead-url=no|df=}} While France and USA voice strong support for the changes and voted in favor of the move, others, such as Australia, were against the new format.{{cite web|url=https://www.sport24.co.za/Tennis/itf-delegates-approve-radical-davis-cup-overhaul-20180816|title=ITF delegates approve radical Davis Cup overhaul|website=Sport24.co.za|access-date=2018-09-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180817113120/https://www.sport24.co.za/Tennis/itf-delegates-approve-radical-davis-cup-overhaul-20180816|archive-date=2018-08-17|dead-url=no|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/43202373|title=Davis Cup: ITF plans to introduce 18-team World Cup of Tennis Finals in revamp|date=26 February 2018|website=Bbc.com|access-date=2018-09-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181113225108/https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/43202373|archive-date=2018-11-13|dead-url=no|df=}}{{Excessive citations inline |date=November 2018}} After the vote, French player Nicolas Mahut tweeted, "The Davis Cup died, and a part of the history of our sport flew away for a handful of dollars". Other players on the circuit including [[Novak Djokovic]], [[Andy Murray]], and [[Rafael Nadal]] have publicly supported the new idea.{{cite web|url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/gerard-pique-s-tennis-world-cup-plan-backed-by-andy-murray-novak-djokovic-and-rafael-nadal_sto6162644/story.shtml|title=Gerard Pique's 'Tennis World Cup' plan backed by English player Andy Murray, Serbian Novak Djokovic and fellow Spaniard Rafael Nadal|date=12 May 2017|website=Eurosport.com|access-date=2018-08-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181113170045/https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/gerard-pique-s-tennis-world-cup-plan-backed-by-andy-murray-novak-djokovic-and-rafael-nadal_sto6162644/story.shtml|archive-date=2018-11-13|dead-url=no|df=}} Lleyton Hewitt of Australia strongly opposes the new initiative as an erosion of the 100-year-old tradition of the Davis Cup.{{cite web|url=http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2018/08/weighing-pros-and-cons-itfs-roll-dice-davis-cup-revamp/76079/|title=Weighing the pros and cons of the ITF's roll-the-dice Davis Cup revamp|website=Tennis.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.com/2018/08/04/tennis-itf-defend-3-billion-davis-cup-revamp-despite-criticism|title=Tennis - ITF defend $3 billion Davis Cup revamp despite criticism|date=4 August 2018|website=Euronews.com|access-date=2018-09-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181113210814/https://www.euronews.com/2018/08/04/tennis-itf-defend-3-billion-davis-cup-revamp-despite-criticism|archive-date=2018-11-13|dead-url=no|df=}}{{Failed verification|date=November 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Companies based in Barcelona]] [[Category:Sports]] [[Category:Business]]

page.title: List of NFL quarterbacks who have posted a perfect passer rating

revision.comment: /* Statistics */ including Peyton Manning's achievement in 2003-04 regular season/post-season
revision.text:
In the [[National Football League]] (NFL), the highest official [[passer rating]] that a quarterback can achieve is 158.3, which is considered a perfect passer rating. To [[Passer rating#NFL|qualify]], a quarterback must attempt at least 10 passes, have zero interceptions, and have minimums of a 77.5% completion percentage, 11.88% touchdown passes percentage, and 12.5 yards per attempt. The passer rating was developed in 1971.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-statistics.com/Greats/Century/passer-rating.htm |title=Passer Rating Formula |publisher=Baseball-statistics.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.profootballhof.com/history/release.aspx?release_id=1303 |title=History Release » NFL's Passer Rating |publisher=Profootballhof.com |date=2010-02-07 |accessdate=2011-11-15}}</ref>
Applying the formula to pre and post-1971 quarterbacks, {{As of|2018|11|df=US|lc=y}}, there have been 60 different players, on 72 occasions, who have achieved a perfect passer rating. Four of these ratings have occurred in the post-season. Seven quarterbacks have achieved the feat more than once: [[Ben Roethlisberger]] and [[Peyton Manning]] have four; [[Kurt Warner]] has three; and [[Craig Morton]], [[Dave Krieg]], [[Ken O'Brien]], and [[Tom Brady]] have two.
Ben Roethlisberger is the only quarterback with multiple perfect ratings in a single regular season, when he achieved the feat twice in 2007. The [[San Francisco 49ers]] had two different quarterbacks achieve a perfect rating in the same season, with [[Steve Young (American football)|Steve Young]] (week 7) and [[Joe Montana]] (week 10) both earning perfect ratings. Peyton Manning had one perfect rating in the 2003 regular season and one in the post-season.
[[Drew Bledsoe]], [[Robert Griffin III]], and [[Marcus Mariota]] are the only quarterbacks to achieve a perfect passer rating in their rookie seasons, with Mariota being the only quarterback to post one in his NFL debut.
Four of these performances were in a losing cause, though [[Chad Pennington]] is the only quarterback to play from start to finish and earn both a loss and a perfect rating. Twelve quarterbacks have had a perfect 158.3 passer rating and also [[List of NFL quarterbacks who have posted a passer rating of zero|earned a 0.0]] (lowest) passer rating during their careers: [[Otto Graham]], [[Johnny Unitas]], [[Joe Namath]], [[Terry Bradshaw]], [[Len Dawson]], [[Bob Griese]], [[James Harris (quarterback)|James Harris]], [[Bob Lee (quarterback)|Bob Lee]], [[Craig Morton]], [[Dan Fouts]], [[Eli Manning]], and [[Peyton Manning]].
[[Pittsburgh Steelers]] quarterback [[Ben Roethlisberger]] is the latest person to achieve a perfect passer rating.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/boxscore?gameId=401030729 |title=Panthers vs. Steelers - Box Score - November 8, 2018 |website=ESPN.com |date=2018-11-08 |accessdate=2018-11-08}}</ref>

==Statistics== Only three quarterbacks have accomplished a perfect passer rating with 30 or more attempts. Ken O'Brien threw 26-for-32 in his perfect game for a completion rate of 81%, while Kurt Warner threw 24 of 30 in his perfect game for a completion rate of 80% and Jared Goff threw 26 of 33 in his perfect game for a completion rate of 78.8%. Ryan Tannehill holds the record for completion rate in a perfect game, throwing 18 of 19 for 94.7% in his 2015 perfect game. Chris Chandler has the best rate for a game with at least 20 pass attempts (23 of 26) for 88% completed in his 1995 perfect game.
Only Nick Foles has accomplished a perfect passer rating with seven touchdowns thrown. Two quarterbacks have accomplished a perfect passer rating with six touchdowns thrown: Peyton Manning was the first to achieve the record on September 28, 2003 against the New Orleans Saints, while Tom Brady matched the feat on October 21, 2007 against the Miami Dolphins. Thirteen quarterbacks have accomplished a perfect game with only two touchdowns thrown. It is impossible to achieve a perfect game with only one touchdown because of the 10 passing attempt minimum to qualify, combined with the minimum 11.875% touchdown-to-attempted-pass ratio.
Three quarterbacks have accomplished a perfect passer rating with more than 400 passing yards. Ken O'Brien threw for 431 yards on November 2, 1986 against the Seattle Seahawks. Nick Foles threw for 406 yards on November 3, 2013 against the Oakland Raiders. Jared Goff threw for 465 yards on September 27, 2018 against the Minnesota Vikings. Only three quarterbacks have accomplished a perfect game with fewer than 150 passing yards. Scott Hunter threw for 138 yards on October 31, 1976 against the New Orleans Saints, Drew Bledsoe threw for 143 yards on December 26, 1993 against the Indianapolis Colts, and Rich Gannon threw for 146 yards on October 15, 1992 against the Detroit Lions.
Only three quarterbacks have accomplished a perfect passer rating in their rookie season. Drew Bledsoe of the New England Patriots achieved it against the Indianapolis Colts on December 26, 1993; Robert Griffin III of the Washington Redskins did it against the Philadelphia Eagles on November 18, 2012; and Marcus Mariota of the Tennessee Titans did it against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers on September 13, 2015, the first quarterback to do so in his professional debut. Only one QB, Ben Roethlisberger, has accomplished a perfect passer rating twice in one season, against the Ravens on November 5, 2007; and against the St. Louis Rams on December 20, 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/R/RoetBe00/gamelog/2007/ |title=Ben Roethlisberger 2007 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2017-03-20}}</ref>. Peyton Manning had one perfect rating in the 2003 regular season and one in the post-season.
==See also== *[[Perfect game]] (baseball) *[[Shutout]] (ice hockey) *[[300-point game]] (bowling) *[[Maximum break]] (snooker) *[[Nine dart finish]] (darts) *[[List of NFL quarterbacks who have posted a passer rating of zero]] *[[List of 500-yard passing games in the National Football League]]

revision.text:
The '''National High School Rugby Tournament''' is held annually since 1917 at [[Higashi Osaka Hanazono Rugby Stadium]] in [[Higashiosaka, Osaka|Higashi Osaka]], [[Japan]] from the end of December to early January. All 47 [[Prefectures of Japan]] are represented, with four extra teams (one from [[Hokkaidō]], one from [[Tokyo]], and two from [[Osaka]] prefecture) to make up the numbers.
== Strongest Teams ==
Some of the strongest teams, with their prefectures in brackets, are as follows:
* Keiko Gakuen ([[Osaka]]) - four times champion in succession, 2001-4 * Higashi Fukuoka ([[Fukuoka]]) * Sendai Ikuei ([[Sendai]]) * Tenri ([[Nara, Nara|Nara]]) * [[Saga Technical High School|Saga Kogyo]] ([[Saga, Saga|Saga]]) * Ōita Maizuru ([[Ōita, Ōita|Ōita]]) * Tokai Dai Gyosei (Osaka)
==See also==
*[[Rugby union in Japan]] *[[Sanix World Rugby Youth Invitational Tournament]]
==External links== *[http://rugby.mbs.jp/ Mainichi Broadcasting System] page about the tournament (Japanese)
