{{refimprove|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox settlement <!-- See Template:Infobox settlement for additional fields and descriptions --> | name = Skatepark of Tampa | image_skyline = Skateparkoftampalogo.jpg | image_caption = Skatepark of Tampa Logo | subdivision_type = Location | subdivision_name = [[Tampa, Florida]], United States | established_title = Opened | established_date = 28 December 1992 | website = {{URL|http://spottampa.com}} }} The '''Skatepark of Tampa''' is a [[skatepark]] in [[Tampa, Florida]], United States. It is considered one of the top [[skateboarding]] venues on the East Coast of the United States. The name is often abbreviated as ''SPoT'', and it is well known for its annual ''Tampa Am'' and ''[[Tampa Pro (skateboard competition)|Tampa Pro]]'' competitions.<ref>{{cite news|title=Skateboarding glory rolls through Tampa event|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2006/03/11/Sports/Skateboarding_glory_r.shtml|accessdate=28 June 2013|newspaper=Tampa Bay Times|date=11 March 2006|author=Bob Putnam}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=TAMPA AM 2012 FINALS|url=http://skateboarding.transworld.net/1000170061/videos/tampa-am-2012-finals/|work=Transworld Skateboarding|publisher=Bonnier Corporation|accessdate=28 June 2013|author=TWS|date=10 December 2012}}</ref>
== History == On December 28, 1992, SPoT was opened only to employees, and on January 2, 1993 the park officially opened to the public.<ref>{{cite web|title=THE 18TH ANNUAL TAMPA AM|url=http://espn.go.com/action/skateboarding/story/_/id/8721767/the-skatepark-tampa-celebrates-their-20-year-anniversary-weekend-tampa-contest|work=X Games|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=28 June 2013|author=Chris Nieratko|date=9 December 2012}}</ref>
On April 1, 2012, SPoT announced on its website that the park had been purchased (for {{USD}}9.3 million) by rapper [[Lil Wayne]]. It was revealed shortly afterwards that the fake press release was an [[April Fool's]] joke.<ref>{{cite web|title=LIL WAYNE BUYS MAJORITY OWNERSHIP IN SKATEPARK OF TAMPA FOR $9.3 MILLION|url=http://skateparkoftampa.com/spot/a.aspx?ID=1732|work=Skatepark of Tampa|publisher=Skatepark of Tampa|accessdate=28 June 2013|author=Rob Meronek|date=1 April 2012}}</ref>
== Obstacles == {{Unreferenced section|date=June 2013}} The skatepark includes a [[terrain park]]-style "pro course", offering a [[funboxpyramid]] and many difficult rails for [[Grinds (skateboarding)|grinds]] and [[Slides (skateboarding)|slides]]. Outside, there is a concrete transition course with a pizza oven. The "beginner's course" features many smaller rails and ramps to expand skateboarding skills and also includes the famous bowl.
The [[street skateboarding]] course is redesigned every year for the Tampa Pro and Tampa Am contest.<ref>http://skateparkoftampa.com/spot/a.aspx?ID=3038</ref>
== Team == we only sponsor Colonel Sanders .<ref>{{cite web|title=SKATEPARK OF TAMPA TEAMS|url=http://skateparkoftampa.com/team|work=Skatepark of Tampa|publisher=Skatepark of Tampa|accessdate=28 June 2013|author=Rob Meronek|date=13 April 2007}}</ref>
===Skateboarding=== Pro: *[[Elissa Steamer]] *Jeff Lenoce *Matt Milligan *Mike Frazier *Clive Dixon *Jimmy Marcus aka "The Greek" *Mike Frazier *Brian Schaefer *Paul Zitzer *Tyson Peterson *Zion Wright
Am: *Abdias Rivera *Sam Bellipanni *Eric McKenney *Markus Jalaber *James Cobb *Wes Box *Cash Gaddes *Robby Kirkland *Treshan O'Shaugnessy *Alejandro Burnell *Alex Johnson *Allen Russell *Pat Stiener *Marse Farmer
===Party=== *Adam Dyet *Allen Russell *Braydon Szafranski *Brian Schaefer *Chris Peck *David Gravette *Don Brown *DJ Wade *Bart Simpson *Marty McFly *Joey Brezinski *Justin Strubing *Lizard King *Matt Milligan *Oliver Flores *Omar Hassan *Pat Duffy *P-Stone *Cory Kennedy *Keenan Milton *Ali Boulala *Shane Cross
===Family=== *Brian Howard *Brian Sloane *Corey Hainline *Dorian Tucker *Jay Giroux *Josh Stewart *Kyle Berard *Mike Peterson *Paul Zitzer *Ryan Dodge *Scotty Conley *Steve Brandi
===BMX=== *Spencer Foresman *Mark Mulville *Matt Coplon *Luis (aka Project Pap) Pinzon *Jeff Harrington *Sean Albright
===Business=== *Chris Kneer *George Lackey *Henry Alva *Jimmy Hurn *Michael J. Buscemi *Wesley Cowan
== Music venue == The skatepark also doubles as a popular music venue. In 2012, SPoT hosted its 20-year anniversary event with performances from [[Souls of Mischief]] and [[Killer Mike]].<ref>{{cite news|title=SoundCheck: Aerosmith, Geoff Tate, Sum 41, Ty Segall, METZ Skatepark of Tampa 20-Year Anniversary Party, Iris DeMent|url=http://www.tampabay.com/features/music/soundcheck-aerosmith-geoff-tate-sum-41-skatepark-of-tampa-20-year/1264743|accessdate=28 June 2013|newspaper=Tampa Bay Times|date=5 December 2012|author=Jay Cridlin}}</ref>
The venue also hosts the ''Transitions Art Gallery'' music venue on its premises. TAG has served as a springboard for acoustic artists and other musicians. In December 2012, the owner of the Gallery announced he was stepping down and that the venue would be under new management from January 2013. The venue's new owners subsequently announced that the name of the venue would change to ''Epic Problem''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Skatepark of Tampa's Transitions Art Gallery gets new owners, changing name to Epic Problem|url=http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/soundcheck/content/skatepark-tampas-transitions-art-gallery-gets-new-owners-changing-name-epic-problem|accessdate=28 June 2013|newspaper=Tampa Bay Times|date=7 December 2012|author=Jay Cridlin}}</ref> ''Epic Problem'' hosts many shows from many post-hardcore bands and one annual show from the nonprofit high school (mainly from [[Hillsborough High School (Tampa, Florida)|Hillsborough High School]]) sketch comedy troupe On The Brink.<ref>http://www.hhstoday.com/life/2015/02/12/on-the-brink-march-12-14/</ref>
In July 2016, Epic Problem held its last show and passed the torch to King State coffee, owned by Tim McTague, of [[Underoath]] and Nate Young, of [[Anberlin]], who use the space for brewing.<ref>{{cite web|title=KING STATE COFFEE TAKING OVER TAMPA'S TRANSITION ART GALLERY|url=http://www.cltampa.com/music/music-news/article/20830577/king-state-coffee-taking-over-tampas-transitions-art-gallery|author=Ray Roa|date=11 August 2016|newspaper=Creative Loafing}}</ref>
In March 2017, the SPoT Snack Bar was expanded and reconstructed into a full-fledged music venue and renamed "Transitions". It is complete with stage, lighting, sound system and newly rebuilt bar. Transitions held its first show during the 23rd Annual Tampa Pro contest that featured the music of [[Ray Barbee]], Drowning Clowns, Arctic, and Tampa's own Samurai Shotgun.
==Popular culture== The skatepark is a major feature in the ''[[Tony Hawk's Underground]]'' video game, and SPoT employees appear as competitors in the street and vertical contests. The skatepark also served as an exclusive competition level in ''[[Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 2x]]''.<ref>http://skateparkoftampa.com/article/173/SPoT_on_THuG</ref>
SPoT appeared on the MTV series ''[[Rob & Big]]'' that featured professional skateboarder and entrepreneur [[Rob Dyrdek]].<ref>http://www.mtv.com/episodes/spvr8h/rob-and-big-tampa-season-2-ep-206</ref>
In August 2011, [[Lil Wayne]] stopped by SPoT for a private after hours session. He has attended every Tampa Pro contest since, often spectating from the judges' booth.<ref>http://skateparkoftampa.com/article/1605/Lil_Wayne_Skateboarding_at_Skatepark_of_Tampa</ref>
In May 2004, comedian [[Dave Chappelle]] set up an after hours session with some of his friends while on tour in Tampa.<ref>http://skateparkoftampa.com/article/229/Dave_Chappelle_&_Posse_Take_Lessons</ref>

{{Bowling techniques sidebar |expanded=all}} In [[cricket]], a '''slider''' is a type of delivery bowled by a [[wrist spin]] bowler. While a [[topspinner]] is released with the thumb facing the batsman, a slider is bowled in a similar manner to a legbreak, but instead of imparting sidespin with the third finger, the bowler allows his fingers to roll down the back of the ball, providing a mixture of sidespin and backspin. Whereas a topspinner tends to dip more quickly and bounce higher than a normal delivery, a slider does the opposite: it carries to a fuller length and bounces less than the batsman might expect. The sliders will typically head towards the batsman with a scrambled seam (with the ball not spinning in the direction of the seam, so the seam direction is not constant, unlike in conventional spin bowling). This has less effect on the flight and bounce but absence of [[leg spin]] may deceive the batsman. Frequently the slider is bowled with a mixture of side spin and backspin. This has the effect of making the ball harder to differentiate from the leg break for the batsmen without reducing the mechanical effects caused by the backspin. This delivery may skid straight on or it may turn a small amount.<ref name="Wisden">{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/287315.html|last=Atherton|first=Michael|title=Wisden Cricketers' Almanack 2007 - Shane Warne The mighty craftsman|date=24 March 2007|accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref>
It is claimed that [[Shane Warne]] invented this type of delivery. However, this is inaccurate. The Australian spinner [[Peter Philpott]] used the technique in the 1960s, calling it simply an orthodox backspinner, while Australian all - rounder and captain [[Richie Benaud]] used what he called his 'sliding topspinner' which appears again to have been similar. Since he was taught the technique by [[Doug Ring]],<ref name="Wisden"/> it may be more accurate to suggest that Ring is the originator. Either that, or the ball is one of those deliveries with no easily identifiable point of origin. However Shane Warne's use of the delivery in the 2005 Ashes brought the variation once more into the public consciousness. His dismissal of [[Ian Bell]] lbw with the delivery was a classic piece of spin bowling; Bell played for the turn of a normal leg break, but the delivery skidded straight into his front pad without turning.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2005/jul/25/ashes2005.ashes|last=Haigh|first=Gideon|title=Sliders rule as Warne is recalibrated|date=25 July 2005|newspaper=Guardian|location=London|accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref>
Although there is often a good deal of confusion on the subject, the slider is thought to be more or less an identical delivery to the "zooter".<ref>[http://mpafirsteleven.blogspot.com/2010/11/orthodox-back-spinner-part-ii.html]</ref>
[[Finger spin]] bowlers commonly bowl an exactly equivalent ball, which comes out of the front of the hand with backspin present. However the name slider has not passed over into common parlance for its offspin cousin, and the terms [[arm ball]], '''backspinner''' or, more recently, [[teesra]] are used instead.
==See also== *[[Cricket terminology]] *[[Leg spin]]

revision.text:
The '''Tipton Road''' [[cricket ground]] in [[Dudley]], [[England]] was used for [[first-class cricket]] by [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire CCC]] on 88 occasions between 1911 and 1971. The county also staged 14 [[List A cricket|List A]] games there between 1969 and 1977, all in the [[National League (cricket)|Sunday League]], as well as a number of Second XI matches.
One match of the [[1982 ICC Trophy]] was played at Tipton Road, but the game between [[East African cricket team|East Africa]] and [[West African cricket team|West Africa]] was abandoned without a result after East Africa had reached 53/2 from 25.1 overs.
On 25 May 1985, however, a 40-foot wide hole appeared on the cricket pitch, and Dudley council immediately closed the cricket pitch and the rest of the sports centre.
The whole complex remained derelict until the late 1990s, when construction of the first buildings on the [[Castle Gate, Dudley|Castle Gate]] leisure and commercial complex began.<ref>[http://www.blackcountrysociety.co.uk/articles/hole-in-the-ground/]</ref>
==Records== ===First-class=== * '''Highest team total:''' 645/7 declared by [[Warwickshire County Cricket Club|Warwickshire]] v Worcestershire, 1914 * '''Lowest team total:''' 48 by Worcestershire v [[Gloucestershire County Cricket Club|Gloucestershire]], 1924 * '''Highest individual innings:''' 305 [[not out]] by [[Frank Foster (cricketer)|Frank Foster]] for Warwickshire v Worcestershire, 1914 * '''Best bowling in an innings:''' 9-45 by [[Peter Jackson (cricketer)|Peter Jackson]] for Worcestershire v Somerset, 1935
===List A=== * '''Highest team total:''' 258/4 (40 overs) by Worcestershire v Sussex, 1972<ref name="WvS">Same match.</ref> * '''Lowest team total:''' 88 (32.1 overs) by Sussex v Worcestershire, 1972<ref name="WvS">Same match.</ref> * '''Highest individual innings:''' 121 by [[Glenn Turner]] for Worcestershire v Sussex, 1972<ref name="WvS">Same match.</ref> * '''Best bowling in an innings:''' 5-28 by [[David Acfield]] for Essex v Worcestershire, 1972
==Notes== <references />
==References== * [http://cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Grounds/11/456/index.html Tipton Road, Dudley - Records] from CricketArchive. Retrieved 9 December 2006.
